metadata.synopsis: After the death of his wife, Sam Baldwin (Tom Hanks) moves to Seattle with his son, Jonah (Ross Mallinger). When Jonah calls in to a talk-radio program to find a new wife for his father, Sam grudgingly gets on the line to discuss his feelings. Annie Reed (Meg Ryan), a reporter in Baltimore, hears Sam speak and falls for him, even though she is engaged. Unsure where it will lead, she writes Sam a letter asking him to meet her at the Empire State Building on Valentine's Day.

reviews: Despite a madcap, slapstick type of comic conclusion, with no real hope of marital longevity, the film is terribly romantic.
Sleepless in Seattle finds a way to put a fresh seasoning on top of the genre.
What are we teaching the other little sons of America, when they see so few movies as humane and woman-positive as Sleepless in Seattle, and so very many that portray women as evil incarnate?

The emotional weight of the drama rests on Hanks, and you appreciate how skilfully Ephron structures the film so that the two principals are bound by song and sentiment rather than physical proximity.
But the movie's problems go deeper-than the dialogue: its whole premise is flawed.
Sleepless In Seattle balances romance and realism by giving its central characters two different but equally pragmatic philosophies on love.

The rest of this romantic comedy about the strange power that pulls a man and woman together... only reinforces the notion that Ephron is a filmmaker whose time has come at last, after years as a novelist, screenwriter and feminist wit.
"Sleepless in Seattle" (citywide), a real charmer, is a romantic comedy about an ultimate long-distance relationship. Emphasize "romantic." Emphasize "comedy." It delivers both.
For nearly two hours, Ephron keeps her marvellous stars apart, a potentially dangerous tactic that works superbly.
Substantially better, funnier, smarter, and more impeccably-controlled than almost everything that came in its wake.
While I have returned to watch my favourite moments play out again and again, I am always rewarded by the subtlety and beauty in the scenes I don't remember.
...a decent drama that never entirely lives up to its place as a classic romcom...

Self-consciousness infects Nora Ephron's sweet but perilously thin love story, Sleepless in Seattle...such are the perils of these postmodernist times: even our love stories feed off borrowed emotion.
A movie to which director and co-writer Nora Ephron brought her terrific flair, wit and nous, although she propagates the terrifying fallacy that a widower makes a wonderful romantic catch.
Don't get me wrong: I have no objection to shamelessly corny love stories that make you well up with tearful joy. I just don't like it when the movie does the welling up for you.
A fairy tale that even teens can enjoy.
A romantic treat.
Mostly, Sleepless in Seattle leaves you feeling restless in the audience.
If one can ignore all the straining for lightness here, this is watchable enough, though hardly anything resembling a tearjerker.
Ephron and fellow writers Jeff Arch and David S. Ward have conspired to make Sleepless in Seattle as purposefully schmaltzy as one can imagine, in a manner that's almost cynical.
